description.narrative:
Background: The mining sector is one of the most privileged industries in the Mexican economy and must be effectively regulated in order to ensure a fair collection of taxes, and promote budget allocations that address the expressed needs of mining communities, further Human Rights and guarantee environmental sustainability.
Oxfam Mexico contends that the biggest changes needed to improve mining industry regulation pertain to the local: how policies are implemented and monitored, who really participates in decision making and how barriers can be breached all incorporate local efforts. Yet the changes enacted in 2019 for the 2020 budget and the proposed changes to the structure of off-budget trust funds (which the Fondo Minero technically is) are moving in the opposite direction: towards re-centralization, and towards increasing opacity and hampering any possibility of community monitoring.
Project: The proposed project will produce research and lead advocacy activities aimed at shedding light on where we are, how the mining industry#s fiscal allocations are collected and spent, and how communities can tap into and monitor these resources. We explore fiscal information and community engagement mechanisms that guarantee the rights and meet the needs of mining communities, that make the resources and projects financed by the mining fund transparent, and incorporate citizen participation--as well as the participation of communities affected by mining#in the long term, whatever the destination of the resources in the short term.
Goal: The proposed project seeks to improve the fiscal transparency of mining activities in Mexico and improve fiscal justice, by ensuring mining companies contribute in proportion to what they take, and contributions helpcommunities affected by mining projects advance development goals (and, ideally, mitigate risk).
Activities: To do this, the project has organized activities around four specific goals: 1. Improve the transparency of mining sector taxation; 2. Evidence the effect of austerity policies over mining affected communities; 3. Strengthen capacities in local organizations and communities to understand mining sector taxation and private sector / state obligations, and demand these obligations are met; and 4. Advance fiscal justice # crafting evidence and arguments supporting fair taxation of the mining sector and targeted budget allocations

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam International’s decision to incorporate new members, especially from emerging developing countries, is part of its aim to become a more global, relevant and effective organization to promote social change as a culturally diverse confederation working from several different priority approaches and strategies.
Oxfam Mexico (OM) is the first formal member of the confederation incorporatedthrough this process. As a Mexican organization with a history of its own and links to other Latin American countries, Oxfam Mexicohas joined the confederation with Mexco's perspective of Oxfam's role in the region, hoping to contribute to enrich it.
International cooperation in Latin America and the Caribbean is clearly following a new trend: on one hand, overall funding is being reduced and, on the other, funds are now being channelled to build the States' public policy and institutional capacities. As a result of their economic dynamism, several countries in the region are no longer "poor countries" strictly speaking and have announced overcoming social inequality as their main challenge. They are attempting to transform their social and economic policies seeking to improve the distribution of wealth, rebuild their institutional architecture grounded in democracy and transparency, and establish a new relationship between governments and civil society. In an increasingly interconnected and interdependent world, these changes have stirred the debate over the role played by the region and, in particular, the countries with the most dynamic economies in the world. This situation has changed the perspective of our responsibilities and contribution to the fight to overcome the current global crisisand poverty. Oxfam Mexico has an added value for the work of Oxfam International.
